ygData.subject: Re: Build Failed With Maven
ygData.msgSnippet: Hello, It looks like I might be having some similar-ish problems to Yousef - am currently trying to build a fresh jar, on a PC / WinXP system. Haven t made any

Hello,
It looks like I might be having some similar-ish problems to Yousef - 
am currently trying to build a fresh jar, on a PC / WinXP system. 
Haven't made any adjustments to the code yet, but am failing the 
following unit tests:

XMLSettingsHandlerTest
DiskBackedDequeTest
DiskBackedQueueTest
DiskQueueTest
DiskStackTest

I tried changing DiskStack.lazyInitialize() to specify 'rw' instead 
of 'rws', as suggested elsewhere, on the off-chance it might help, 
but no joy. I've chased a couple of the more serious failures (i.e. 
actual exceptions, as opposed to just Assert problems) in more 
detail, see below. 

Having said that, the new jar does basically seem to still work, but 
failed Unit tests are never a good thing..! I know that Windows isn't 
a supported platform, so on my own head be it, but any suggestions as 
to the problem would be much appreciated, as I'm still feeling in the 
dark here quite a bit!

Jim K

DISK QUEUE TEST
A NoSuchElementException occurs, basically because the queue being 
read seems to be in an EOF state. I've done some debugging in 
DiskQueueTest.testIterator(), and have found that if you comment out 
the use of queue.getIterator i.e. just do queueing and enqueueing, it 
works fine. But as soon as you get an iterator (whether you then move 
through it or not), that leaves the queue in an EOF state, and your 
next dequeue crashes out.

- <testcase name="testIterator" time="0.047">
  <error 
type="java.util.NoSuchElementException">java.util.NoSuchElementExcepti
on at org.archive.util.DiskQueue.dequeue(DiskQueue.java:191) at

(DiskQueueTest.java:133)




DISK BACKED DEQUEUE TEST (and similar problem in DISK BACKED QUEUE 
TEST):
An IOException occurs in TestSerializationBoth, when it tries to 
write the queue object to the ObjectPlusFilesOutputStream. The error 
details below indicate a 'file not found' problem involving two 
foo.quot files. And there certainly is no sign of any such files 
anywhere on my dir. In the exception message (below), I did notice:

   ln C:\heritrix-1.0.4\target\test-tmp\foo.qout C:\heritrix-1.0.4
\target\test-tmp\serialization\foo.qout 

   This isn't a Linux shell command that's snuck in somehow, is it..?


- <testcase name="testSerialization" time="0.015">
  <error message="CreateProcess: ln C:\heritrix-1.0.4\target\test-
tmp\foo.qout C:\heritrix-1.0.4\target\test-tmp\serialization\foo.qout

DISK STACK TEST
There's an Assert failure in CTorBadFile i.e. it's successfully 
creating the 'uncreatable' file in "/dev" - I wonder if this could be 
due to the different path syntax in Windows and Linux? Am guessing 
this failure might be less serious than the others, though.



--- In archive-crawler@yahoogroups.com, stack <stack@a...> wrote:
> Yousef Ourabi wrote:
> 
> >Hey,
> >Sorry it took me so long to reply to my own question,
> >I just got hit with my first round of midterms.
> >  
> >
> Sorry it took me a while to get back to your reponse (smile).
> 
> You don't say what your platform is.   Your failing in the unit 
tests.  
> You're probably on a Mac, a PC or a 2.6 kernel linux?  If the 
former, 
> you'll need to make a source code change. If the latter, you'll 
need the 
> latest 5.0 JDK (>beta2).  See '[ 984390 ] Build fails: "rws" mode 
and 
> Mac OS X interact badly 
> <http://crawler.archive.org/articles/limitations.html#984390>', in 
Known 
> Limitations for details: 
> http://crawler.archive.org/articles/limitations.html#984390.
> 
> >PS: I configured CVS through Eclipse and I saw two
> >ArchiveOpenCrawler modules? Is this normal? Also I am
> >assuming that is the right module?
> >
> >  
> >
> I've not noticed that before.  Interesting.  One of the lads here 
points 
> out that the icons are slightly different.  I'm guessing its 
something 
> to do with HEAD vs heritrix_1_0 branch.  Maybe someone else can 
explain it.
> 
> St.Ack
